titleInfo.title: Reginald R. Brown, Sr. oral history interview

subject.topic: Baton Rouge Bus Boycott, Baton Rouge, La., 1953

mods.abstract: Brown shares his memories and information gleaned from his parents' generation about the 1953 Baton Rouge Bus Boycott. He describes various aspects of the boycott including the bus system in Baton Rouge and Scotlandville, segregated seating, carpooling and free rides, meetings, organization, and fundraising. He describes the role of black churches and ministers in publicizing the boycott. Brown also discusses sit-ins and marches during the Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s. Brown touches on black churches and businesses in the community, politics and law enforcement in Baton Rouge, and describes changes he's seen over time in the black community since desegregation.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.1018. A digital version of the transcript (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Jeong Suk Pang.

Reginald Brown was born in Baton Rouge, La., in 1946 to Walter and Teresa Bell Brown. He graduated from Thomas A. Levy High School in 1964 and went on to Southern University. He worked as an East Baton Rouge Parish sheriff's deputy for twenty-five years and was elected Baton Rouge City Constable in 2000. Brown has served in organizations such as Holiday Helpers, Inc. of Baton Rouge, Alcohol/Drug Detox Board, the YMCA, and the Louisiana Bar Disciplinary Board. He is the father of two sons and a daughter.
